body:
### Describe the bug

In `cdef` syntax, I can define structs with members that point to the same struct like so:

```cython
cdef struct Node:
    int data
    Node *next
```

However, I can't seem to do the same thing in Pure Python mode. From the docs on structs and pointers, I've come up with the following code:

### Code to reproduce the behaviour:

```python
import cython
Node = cython.struct(
    data=cython.int,
    next=cython.pointer(Node),
)
```


### Expected behaviour

I expect that it should compile similarly to the first snippet.

My current workaround (other than using `cdef` syntax and `.pyx` files) is to declare next as a `cython.p_void` and to do `cython.cast(Node, node.next)` to use it, but it's fairly tedious.


### Environment

OS: Windows 10
Python version 3.9.12
Cython version 3.0.0a11


### Additional context

I posted this question previously in cython-users: [https://groups.google.com/g/cython-users/c/pLIF1ITgC9o](https://groups.google.com/g/cython-users/c/pLIF1ITgC9o). Adding a `Node = cython.struct()` to try to forward declare `Node` unfortunately didn't fix this.

The second snippet errors with the following:

```python
Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
import cython
Node = cython.struct(
    data=cython.int,
    next=cython.pointer(Node),
                        ^
------------------------------------------------------------

node2.py:4:24: Unknown type

Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
import cython
Node = cython.struct(
    data=cython.int,
    next=cython.pointer(Node),
                       ^
------------------------------------------------------------

node2.py:4:23: Unknown type
```
title: [BUG] Recursive struct definition in Pure Python mode
